Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the parent needs to provide it
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story: I stared at my phone, the calendar notification blinking: “Team Meeting in 10 minutes.” My heart thudded. I knew the meeting was just a routine catch-up, and it would be recorded, but I also knew my manager expected everyone to be present and engaged. At the same time, my partner had just texted me: “We’re out of groceries. Can you pick up some things before the store closes? We really need milk and bread for tomorrow.” Money was tight this month, and I’d been picking up extra shifts and watching every dollar. If I left now, I could make it to the store before closing, ensuring my kids had breakfast in the morning. But if I skipped the meeting, would my colleagues think I wasn’t committed? Would my boss notice my absence and question my dedication? I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my family’s needs on one side, my professional responsibilities on the other. My mind raced, torn between being the reliable parent my family depended on and the dependable colleague my team expected.
